items.title: Obama’s Second-Term Options on the Environment
items.author: By Andrew C. Revkin
items.abstract: What Obama can do to cut climate risk and improve the environment in his second term.

items.title: Why India’s Waste-to-Energy Industry Won’t Catch Fire
items.author: By David Ferris
items.abstract: Bureaucracy, turf battles and and demands for bribes make it difficult for a plant to open and stay profitable.

items.title: Because Green Goes With Everything
items.author: By Constance Rosenblum
items.abstract: Ron Shiffman has long advocated for buildings that are both resilient and sustainable.

items.title: Now Atlanta Is Turning Old Tracks Green
items.author: By Robbie Brown
items.abstract: The Atlanta BeltLine is an ambitious proposal to transform 22 miles of vine-covered railroad into parks, housing and public transit around the city.

items.title: Sustaining Cities on a Crowding Planet
items.author: By Andrew C. Revkin
items.abstract: Mayors, builders and others discuss urban options for energy, resilient design, and more on a crowding planet.

items.title: Greener Pastures
items.author: By Alan Ehrenhalt
items.abstract: Charles Montgomery melds urban design and the science of happiness in this globe-trotting exploration of city living.

items.title: As U.S. Aims for Energy Independence, China Heads the Opposite Way
items.author: By Michael Forsythe
items.abstract: China’s reliance on imported oil is rising fast, according to a new study by a government research institute.

items.title: Climate Change Art: That Sinking Feeling
items.author: By Andrew C. Revkin
items.abstract: A sculptor’s view of politicians yammering in the face of rising seas and a warming climate.

items.title: Former Queens Fort Revamped for Work on Ecology
items.author: By Lisa W. Foderaro
items.abstract: Fort Totten Park has a laboratory and sleeping quarters for visiting scientists who are happy to get their fingernails dirty in urban soil.
keywords: New York City Urban Field Station

items.title: Can a Pope Help Sustain Humanity and Ecology?
items.author: By Andrew C. Revkin
items.abstract: The two science academies under Pope Francis hold a rare joint meeting to chart paths to sustainable development.

items.title: Climate Change’s Bottom Line
items.author: By Burt Helm
items.abstract: The Risky Business Project’s well-known business and policy leaders hope its research will persuade companies to prepare for, and help mitigate, climate change.

items.title: Wilmington Seeks a Youthful Energy Downtown
items.author: By Jon Hurdle
items.abstract: Creating a space where young professionals can live, work and play, the Delaware city is encouraging city-center living with a push to build apartments.

items.title: The New School Divests Fossil Fuel Stock and Refocuses on Climate Change
items.author: By John Schwartz
items.abstract: The historically progressive school plans to bolster its curriculum to include more attention in its courses to climate change and sustainability.

items.title: Boerum Hill, Brooklyn: Urban Energy, Brownstone Charm
items.author: By John Freeman Gill
items.abstract: Demand for housing outstrips supply in the neighborhood, which offers both a city environment and a tree-lined, residential feel.

items.title: New York City’s Environment Program Will Focus on Income Inequality
items.author: By Matt Flegenheimer
items.abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio’s reimagined take on the city’s ambitious environmental program will come with a new series of lofty goals and a new name: OneNYC.

items.title: Bill Gates, the ‘Impatient Optimist,’ Lays Out his Clean-Energy Innovation Agenda
items.author: By Andrew C. Revkin
items.abstract: Bill Gates discusses the investment and research efforts he’s pursuing to energize societies without overheating the climate.
keywords: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

items.title: Toxic Moss in Portland, Ore., Shakes City’s Green Ideals
items.author: By Kirk Johnson
items.abstract: When a study found toxic materials on tree trunks in residential neighborhoods of Portland, it produced an upheaval of surprise, anger and fear.

items.title: Art Museums Seek a Green Palette
items.author: By David Gelles
items.abstract: As new institutions sprout up around the country, administrators and architects are incorporating environmentally-friendly design features.
keywords: Berkeley Art Museum and Pacific Film Archive

items.title: Mushroom Suits, Biodegradable Urns and Death’s Green Frontier
items.author: By Katie Rogers
items.abstract: A growing number of products rely on sleek design and online publicity to get people comfortable with an environmentally friendly death.

items.title: Price for a Green Card: $500,000 Stadium Stake
items.author: By Ken Belson
items.abstract: A Major League Soccer franchise owner is promoting a federal program that benefits those who contribute at least $500,000 to infrastructure projects.

items.title: Where Sustainable Travel Is Headed in 2017
items.author: By Shivani Vora
items.abstract: What groups and businesses are doing to make tourism more globally aware in the coming year.

items.title: Goats, Alpacas and (of Course) a Hen: Life on a Hobby Farm
items.author: By Vivian Marino
items.abstract: Retirees who want to stay active and productive — and indulge a passion — are setting up small farms around the country.

items.title: A Voice From Paris on Climate Change
items.author: By Alina Tugend
items.abstract: The Paris mayor, Anne Hidalgo, promotes her city’s bold moves and explains why environmental issues are affecting women more.

items.title: Women’s Crucial Role in Combating Climate Change
items.author: By Alina Tugend
items.abstract: Female mayors around the world, like Zandile Gumede of Durban, South Africa, are joining forces to curb threats to the environment.

items.title: Housing Advocates Vow Sustained Protest of de Blasio Aide
items.author: By J. David Goodman
items.abstract: Activists accuse Alicia K. Glen of bringing a Goldman Sachs model of development to City Hall, which they say doesn’t do enough to help the poorest New Yorkers.

items.title: A Greener, More Healthful Place to Work
items.author: By Richard Schiffman
items.abstract: Biophilic buildings aim not just to leave a minimal carbon footprint but also to promote the health of those who live and work there.

items.title: Trump’s Infrastructure Plan May Ignore Climate Change. It Could Be Costly.
items.author: By Coral Davenport
items.abstract: President Trump wants to spend $1.5 trillion on rebuilding roads and bridges, but experts say failing to account for climate change will add to costs.

items.title: Daylight Saving Time Isn’t Saving Much Energy
items.author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka, Brad Plumer and John Schwartz
items.abstract: And yet we keep pushing the clocks forward. (Also in this week's newsletter: We keep building homes in wildfire-prone areas.)

items.title: A Bold, Divisive Plan to Wean Californians From Cars
items.author: By Conor Dougherty and Brad Plumer
items.abstract: Legislation would allow more home building along transit routes to reduce gas-guzzling commutes. Some who support the goal have denounced the method.

items.title: From a Convention Center’s Roof, ‘Walk-Off Vegetables’
items.author: By James Barron
items.abstract: The Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in Manhattan is planning a rooftop farm of almost an acre that will grow fruits and vegetables to be cooked and served downstairs.
keywords: Javits, Jacob K, Convention Center (Manhattan, NY)

items.title: James DeSantis of ‘Backyard Envy’ Tackles Botany and Body Issues
items.author: By Alex Hawgood
items.abstract: The Brooklyn landscaper has helped create green spaces for Diane von Furstenberg, Calvin Klein and Sies Marjan.

items.title: Tiny Costa Rica Has a Green New Deal, Too. It Matters for the Whole Planet.
items.author: By Somini Sengupta, Alexander Villegas and Celia Talbot Tobin
items.abstract: Costa Rica's first lady is leading a green new deal of sorts for her country. If it succeeds, it would provide a road map to others.

items.title: How Much Green Space Can We Afford During a Housing Crisis?
items.author: By Ginia Bellafante
items.abstract: New Yorkers relentlessly fighting development have brought the city to troubling peak Nimbyism.

items.title: Copenhagen Wants to Show How Cities Can Fight Climate Change
items.author: By Somini Sengupta and Charlotte de la Fuente
items.abstract: The Danish capital wants to be carbon neutral six years from now. Its plan involves wind, recycling and a very innovative ski hill.

items.title: Henry J. Stern, Whose Vast Urban Domain Was Green, Is Dead at 83
items.author: By Robert D. McFadden
items.abstract: Only Robert Moses surpassed Mr. Stern, New York City’s longtime parks commissioner, in ensuring that a teeming population had places to breathe.

items.title: Conservative States Seek Billions to Brace for Disaster. (Just Don’t Call It Climate Change.)
items.author: By Christopher Flavelle
items.abstract: A Trump administration program  to help states prepare for  natural disasters has become a window into the tortured political language of talking about climate change.

items.title: Making Yellow School Buses a Little More Green
items.author: By Ellen Rosen
items.abstract: Some school districts are replacing diesel buses with electric models to benefit students and the environment. But the change is expensive so utilities like Dominion Energy are helping offset the cost.

items.title: What Was Said at Davos on Climate Change
items.author: By The New York Times
items.abstract: Global leaders attending the World Economic Forum in Switzerland agree that a rapid response is needed to stave off disaster.

items.title: Coronavirus, U.K. Quarantine, Climate Change: Your Monday Briefing
items.author: By Isabella Kwai
items.abstract: Here’s what you need to know.

items.title: Helping the Environment, One Small Sensor at a Time
items.author: By Ellen Rosen
items.abstract: New York City nonprofits are using a cloud-based service from the start-up Temboo that helps monitor storm-water runoff and other environmental factors.

items.title: For Travel, a Sustainable Comeback?
items.author: By Elaine Glusac
items.abstract: From a newly certified Whale Heritage Site to scenic byways for electric cars, five new initiatives suggest the travel industry may be envisioning a more responsible future.

items.title: Riders Are Abandoning Buses and Trains. That’s a Problem for Climate Change.
items.author: By Somini Sengupta, Geneva Abdul, Manuela Andreoni and Veronica Penney
items.abstract: Public transit offers a simple way for cities to lower greenhouse gas emissions, but the pandemic has pushed ridership, and revenue, off a cliff in many big systems.

items.title: More Than a Third of Heat Deaths Are Tied to Climate Change, Study Says
items.author: By John Schwartz
items.abstract: Sweeping new research found that 37 percent of heat-related deaths on average during warm seasons were attributable to global warming

items.title: China’s Concrete Jungles Make Room for Green Space
items.author: By Keith Bradsher
items.abstract: A national push to build urban parks is transforming Chinese cities, as the country tries to improve the quality of daily life.

items.title: An Architect With an Eye on the Environment
items.author: By Shivani Vora
items.abstract: Increasingly, architects and builders are thinking about how their creations affect the health of the planet. Kunle Adeyemi has built his career around that question.

items.title: These Carbon-Spewing Vehicles Must Be Stopped
items.author: By Margo Oge and Drew Kodjak
items.abstract: To meet his climate goals, President Biden must be more aggressive in ending new truck and bus emissions.

items.title: A Million More Trees for New York City: Leaders Want a Greener Canopy
items.author: By Dana Rubinstein
items.abstract: The city’s five borough presidents are also urging the mayor to honor a pledge to spend 1 percent of the municipal budget on parks.

items.title: They Fled for Greener Pastures, and There Were Weeds
items.author: By Julie Lasky
items.abstract: City dwellers, who retreated to rural areas in the pandemic, now see drawbacks, from pests and social isolation to the difficulty of finding day care and health care.

items.title: The Next Level in Sustainability: Nature Restoration
items.author: By Patrick Sisson
items.abstract: Developers are no longer aiming to simply preserve nature, but are actively restoring it as a selling point for their projects.

items.title: Here’s what Biden’s budget would do, and not do, for climate change
items.author: By Somini Sengupta
items.abstract: The president’s federal spending proposal for the next year contains almost $45 billion to deal with global warming. We looked at the details.

items.title: A Deal to Help South Africa Is a Breakthrough for the World
items.author: By The Editorial Board
items.abstract: A plan to promote the shift to renewable energy could lead to real progress on climate change.

items.title: Baghdad Loses Green Space to Real Estate Boom
items.author: By Jane Arraf, Yasmine Mosimann and Emily Garthwaite
items.abstract: The problem is driving up temperatures in what is already one of the hottest cities in the world, where air-conditioning is a luxury only the rich can afford.

items.title: Golf Course or Housing? A Patch of Green Divides Hong Kong.
items.author: By Joy Dong
items.abstract: The dispute over one of the city’s golf clubs exposes rare political friction for the elite in the new Hong Kong, where the establishment is torn between defending wealth and following Beijing’s wishes.

items.title: They Were Proud Houston Homeowners. Then It All Fell Apart.
items.author: By Jake Bittle
items.abstract: Five years after Hurricane Harvey destroyed their home, Becca and Sergio Fuentes are still rebuilding their lives.
